utterances: Our interview with Alaska Senator Ted Stevens impressed Mark Shepperd(ph) in Waterbury, Connecticut.
He writes: The senator came across as a tough, politically incorrect, stubborn man with strong and not necessarily popular views.
Needless to say, I'd vote for him in a heartbeat.
But many people responded to this exchange in our interview.
(Soundbite of NPR broadcast)
Some people will say, look, I'm very worried about global warming.
Look at the things that are happening in Alaska, for example, but you could point to a lot other places and I think that oil and gas should just stay in the ground.
That oil and gas don't have anything to do with global warming.
How do you make a connection between producing oil in Alaska and global warming?
That global warming comes to the millions of automobiles that are burning the oil.
But if you don't get it from Alaska, you're going to get it offshore.
David Stromberg(ph) writes from Arden Hills, Minnesota: The connection between global warming and drilling for oil in Alaska is pretty straightforward.
By drilling in Alaska, you increase supply, lower prices, and therefore increase consumption.
Lynn Lisberger(?
in Gorham, Maine reflected the views of many who wrote in over the past week about our coverage of the fundraising efforts of presidential candidates.
She writes: How many letters do you have to receive to understand that knowing how much money a candidate raises is not what we want to know about the candidates?
We want to know what their positions are on the issues.
There's a reason we do this.
It's because it's presumed that if you don't raise a lot of money, you're not going to be able to compete later.
So that's why we do it.
(Unintelligible)
We do have some corrections this morning.
Our report on smaller high schools misidentified an influential former president of Harvard University.
It's not James Conant Bryant, but James Bryant Conant.
The first assistant U.S.
attorney in Milwaukee is Michelle Jacobs, which is not what we called her.
And a bit of miscalculation in our story about the giant particle accelerator being built in Europe.
The energy of each particle is not, as we said, equivalent to a speeding bus, but to a mosquito.
It's the combined energy in the accelerator that is equal to a 10-ton bus going 170 miles per hour.
And one of last week's reports sent a listener traveling in time.
Madeleine Landry(ph) or Lafayette, Louisiana listened to the story of the first self-service grocery in New Orleans.
Hurricane Katrina destroyed the store and the long-time owner recently died.
The story reminded Landry of her New Orleans childhood 40 years ago.
Kadanisis(ph) was our Italian grocer.
They delivered free.
My dad loved to hear my mother place the order on the telephone.
She always ordered a dozen breasts and thighs, chicken.
Afterwards, daddy would comment that he found her sexy when she talked like that.
If you want to talk to us, just go to npr.org and click Contact Us.
There's at least one winner in the decline of ad sales: public service announcements.
As NPR's Alison Bryce reports, in the past year there has been a 23 percent increase in PSAs.
It's a really good time to have a cause you want to tell America about.
(Soundbite of PSAs)
Unidentified Woman #1: Last week, I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder.
Unidentified Man #1: Jumping and laziness was crushed.
Unidentified Man #2: Hey kids.
Unidentified Man #3: Mm-hmm.
Unidentified Man #4: One second I'm having a smoke, next thing I know I'm face to face with Smokey Bear.
Unidentified Man #5: One in eight.
A public service announcement brought to you by Feeding America and the Ad Council.
The Ad Council connects non-profits to media outlets and ad agencies.
Ad Council president Peggy Conlon says that stations and networks want to give away their ad time or space, rather than sell it for cheap.

Both broadcast networks and cable networks, local affiliates, radio stations, they all really feel that sense of responsibility to their community and they understand that they have a special platform.
(Soundbite of PSA)
Unidentified Man #6: In 1977, an 8-year-old boy picked up the game of golf from his father.
The odds of that same boy winning the U.S.
Open twice - 1 in 1.2 billion.
The odds of him having a child diagnosed with autism, 1 in 150.
When this commercial was created and the Ad Council put it out there, it was amazing how quickly CBS picked up on that message for their golf programs.
It's kind of embarrassing for everyone that works in the operating room.

Is it a fair observation that when the same job could be done either here or in China, the difference in wages or perhaps the difference in favorable infrastructure, regulation or taxes dictates that job is actually better for GE to put in China than to put in the U.S.
Not always.
I'll move away from China for a second but to Mexico.
We are in process of bringing some jobs from Mexico to places like Decatur, Alabama and Louisville, Kentucky, where we will pay a substantially higher wage than we were paying in Mexico.
But we can do it, because workers are productive, efficient, and able to find other ways to reduce costs.
Are you bringing jobs back from Mexico because of political and the violent situation in Mexico?
No.
No?
No.
No. No. We still have lots of activities that we're proud of in Mexico.
We have a good team of people there, and there's plenty of things that we're happy to be doing in Mexico.
But my point is really about wage rates.
You know, low-cost labor is not the single factor for why you do things in places, because they - wage rates change over time.

When you have productive teams that get up every day thinking about how to do things better, faster, more efficiently, you can offset the impact of whatever wage you're paying in whatever country you're paying it.
I want to ask you about another issue that - well, this pertains once again to China.
GE has a big deal with a big Chinese aviation company.
It's a 50/50 partnership.
And other companies say that if you get involved in a deal like that with the Chinese, first you share technology.

But before long, you're competing against the Chinese company - Siemens has this happened to them - you're competing against the Chinese company that has technology that they gained from you in the partnership.
What guarantees do you have that your intellectual property rights will be respected in China?
We don't have that guarantee anywhere.
But we see things getting better in China, and we have to take a long-term view.
So this 50/50 JV that you referenced is very important for us...
Joint venture that would mean?
Yes.

It's very important for a strategically in our avionics business, and it's a perfect example of where we will create hundreds of engineering jobs in the United States that wouldn't have existed and jobs in China that wouldn't have existed, in order to do this.
And the alternative for us is to be, you know, the fourth largest competitor in that segment of the industry with no real prospect for moving up the list.

As a GE executive, very senior executive based in Hong Kong, do you feel that you're witnessing the country that is going to be dominant economic power, if not more generally the dominant power of 21st-century?
Being in China, do you have any sense of inevitable American decline or you're shaking your head as I'm putting this question.
Quite contrary.
Certainly, I think we're looking at the country that will have largest economy.
But that's very different than the point you are making.
There doesn't have to be anything dominant about it.
They understand that job creation in the U.S.
is important to them, too.
What happens in world if U.S.
economy doesn't work well?
It's not good for anybody.
This world from an environmental perspective, financial is very interrelated.
Well, Mr. Rice, thank you very much...
Thanks.
...for talking with us today.
John Rice, vice chairman of GE and president and CEO of its Global Growth and Operations.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Guy Raz.
